explanation:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 defines dead code as “Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour.” The statement “(void) upload_data_size;” is an expression statement that evaluates the identifier and discards the result; it has no observable side‑effects (upload_data_size is an ordinary pointer, not volatile), so removing that statement would not change program behaviour. Therefore it meets the rule’s definition of dead code. The same reasoning applies to the other (void) parameter casts in the function that only silence compiler warnings.

If upload_data_size (or any of the other parameters) were volatile or the expression had other side effects, removal could affect behaviour — in that case the statement would not be dead code. Absent such side effects, however, the agent A’s report is correct: the cast-to-void statements are dead code under Rule 2.2 and require an approved justification/deviation or an alternative approach to handle unused parameters.
